Review Title: A surprising corner of East London
Review Text: A wild haven in the midst of extensive urban development. Where the wilderness meets the concrete. The river is the perfect frontier.

Next to Canning Town station. A small nature reserve in the middle of a meander of the River Lea. Good informative notice boards and benches at strategic locations. A surprisingly quiet place. Only gulls to see when we visited but sure to be more if you have more time.

It’s a lovely little almost secluded part of Canning Town but it’s quite small and there isn’t a large amount to see. 

The area is surprisingly quiet though. Considering there is a flyover, tube and DLR nearby you can sit in solitude.

Lovely view of the peninsula, however it was so late (10:00pm) when I was there and going home but I think that a few lights will definitely be helpful in order to bring safety to the park as I pass through there a few days of the week.

Review Title: Docklands! A walk on the wild side!
Review Text: Located below the elevated railway track of the DLR this little wild park is perfect place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city! The park site was a former ironworks, shipyard and coal wharf and is now a real wildlife haven consisting of streams, ponds, an outdoor and footpaths

Might be a speck on the map amidst the encroaching developments of a Docklands but this well tended sanctuary harbours a haven for East London life & opportunity to catch local birds wallowing in the mud of the creek. There’s a variety of fauna here, willows, reeds even wild berries & even though peace might be regularly broken by the sound of the DLR rumbling overhead somehow this rare oasis keeps its distance from the everyday bustle going on around it

Interesting place for water birds. Between us, we counted 20 species. Peaceful oasis between industrial area and tower blocks, only disturbed by DLR trains. Being midwinter, quite bare, and I'd like to return in Spring and Autumn. One disappointment, the amount of litter was disgraceful.

Went here to pick up a geocache and was so pleasantly surprised. The park is fairly well kept and the extension plans look good. An abundance of seats to sit and rest in this tranquil area and even a chance to pond dip.

I live a short way from Bow Creek Ecology Park and until two years ago i never actually visited it, the site is horseshoe shaped with the DLR running through the middle so the best time if you can visit the park would be when the DLR is not running over the weekend but dont let that put you off visiting

Review Title: Hidden Gem of London and Industrial History
Review Text:
It opens as a tourist attraction April to November, on Sundays only 11am - 4PM.

I arrived at 3pm expecting a guided tour to be available as it is on most Sundays, but the workers said it was not going ahead that day.
I explained I had come especially for it, and a volunteer guide called Tony said he would give me a tour anyway.
It was excellent.

He explained the history of the mill, the milling equipment inside, the gin trade, and some social history.
He was eloquent and funny and I learnt a lot.

I really recommend a visit, to what has to be one of London's hidden gems which is overlooked by most Londoners.

After the tour I went into the cafe and had a further chat with Tony and Beverly who works there, it was great.
They were very kind to explain lots about the building and the wider site and East London in general.
I cannot thank them highly enough!

I think a typical visit would last one hour, perhaps a bit more as it is nice to have a drink in the cafe and look at a small but well stocked souvenir shop with interesting booklets about the mill and local area.

A visit could be combined with a heritage walk along the adjacent Lea river, very scenic.

The website doesn't describe how to get there well enough, so I will have a go.
I travelled using London Underground, the venue is a six to seven minute walk from the station.
Go to Bromley-By-Bow station on the Hammersmith & City and District Lines.
Exit the station, then turn left and almost immediate right into a subway under the main road flyover.
At the end of the short subway, exit and turn left and head along the slip road (Hancock Road) towards the Tesco petrol station, about a one minute walk.
Keep walking and turn right into Three Mills Lane where on your right is a large Tesco superstore.
Then there is a river, walk across the bridge over the river and The House Mill is on your left.
Press the buzzer marked "Cafe" on the large old blue door to get in.
On your right is another mill with a clock tower which is a different mill, and ahead of you is a security lodge.
If you get to the lodge then you have walked past the House Mill and need to turn back and walk about 30 seconds to the blue door.

Review Title: Fascinating history of tidal energy harnessed since 1066 to produce London gin
Review Text: Please don't be put off by the website! This is the most interesting thing we've done in London so far. This ancient tidal mill is open on Sundays 11-4 pm from April to the end of Nov with the last tour at 3 pm. You do need to book via Facebook, but we got an immediate response and a warm welcome. The hour-long tour with an enthusiastic and knowledgeable volunteer guide takes you from the attic grain silos right down to the old waterwheels and includes some interesting info about the surrounding area too. Afterwards, the bargain £10 tour ticket includes a hot drink in the Millers House cafe. Alternatively, you could treat yourself to a tasty lunch or a slice of cake.

Today we visited Three Mills Island and cafe
The tour of the Tidal Mill was very interesting and informative.  We also had an excellent lunch and coffee
The Mill is I believe staffed by volunteers who are all very committed and passionate and we thoroughly enjoyed our visit

Review Title: U3A trip to an unknown gem
Review Text:
As a group from Essex we have been exploring industrial heritage of the UK. By chance I found the House Mill and realised it would be a great venue for one of our trips. 16 of us had a brilliant tour with excellent food. Definitely worth a visit on a Sunday in the summer or to arrange a tour for a group of 12 or more.
As you will learn it is one of a very few mills powered by the tide
We took the house mill on Sunday 30th April with another couple.Our guide was called Eleanor.The tour was very interesting.We had lunch and tea there also.A great day out!

The welcome was warm when we arrived. However, we were provided with a feedback form to complete and return once the tour was finished. We didn’t have a pen, so decided to do the 21st century thing and leave a Tripadvisor feedback.
We thoroughly enjoyed the guided tour and found it both informative and enjoyable.
The guide was excellent and had an obvious passion for the mill.
Unfortunately on our departure we were accosted by an elderly lady, who asked for our feedback forms… As we were in a hurry to get back to our car to pick up our son, we begin to explain that we didn’t have time, but would leave a review. She became extremely unpleasant and assailed us with accusations of taking advantage of a free tour, without providing any kind of feedback or donation.
I think going forward that if they charged a small fee for the tour, people would know where they stand and would not have to suffer the unpleasant haranguing that we did.
A really disappointing end to a nice visit

Review Title: Great lunch stop when walking The Line
Review Text:
We came across Three Mills Island while walking part of The Line sculpture trail. Of course, due to lockdown, the mill was closed to visitors but we still had delicious sandwiches from their cafe. 

The staff were very friendly, the food was very tasty and the prices were very reasonable. 

I will try to come back when the buildings reopen.

This is a great place to go on a weekend for a little exploration. We had a guided tour by Robert who was very informative and gave an enjoyable presentation. All the people here are volunteers and they are hoping to revive the Mill for educational and also environmental/green energy purposes. Nice little coffee shop and garden if you just want somewhere to go and relax. Well worth supporting.

Recommended for people interested in a bit of lesser known London history, away from the crazy crowds of the big sites.  This mill (and two others next door) played a major part in London's baking and gin history in the late 1700s.   Now run by lovely volunteers, the place is all-original, with the huge water wheels still intact.  We got a great 50 minute tour for £4!  Lots of insights into the unusual physical structure of the building, the milling process, and the insane working conditions back then.  Thanks Robert!  Good coffee and generous  sandwiches in the simple cafe at non-tourist prices. Great views of Bow River too.  Easy access from Bromley-by-Bow underground, or a nice walk from Stratford.

Review Title: In the lower end of Lea Valley (before it goes into Thames), there’s a number of these intrusions
Review Text:
... that look like peninsulas and sometimes like islands. And with a mix of canals and the real river, bridges and land masses become so indistinguishable from each other that google map would suggest you to walk home and take a nap instead.

And there’s this Three Mills Island, a man-made island in the midst of housing developments and conservations. The island can be divided into two parts, the west being a park, the east its mill factories. The clock mill is now a college. The wind mill has gone to wind mills’ virtual cemetery+. The (tidal) water mill is now an attraction, the House Mill I’m trying to tell you about all along.

The miller’s house was destroyed by Blitz bomb(s) and rebuilt as a visitor centre with a café. It connects with the Grade I listed house mill.

No access allowed without a guided tour as I was told that some of the many wooden tiles were dangerous to walk on. Having tried stepping on every pre-warned tile, I'd say they did get rough at times.

Our tour includes a model demonstration (front) of how the tidal mill is supposed to behave. As tidal water is trapped (by a gate, reservoir just upstream of the house) during high tides and subsequently released through the mill, the turning serves two function – grinding grains, as well as bringing up sacks of grain from ground floor to storage.

The mill now rests in peace (you’ll see its corpse towards the end of the tour) and the water gate is long lost. I heard restoration if barely possible would still some time far far away.

+This is a subtle way of saying that the corpse is nowhere to be found.

~master jonjon

Review Title: Guided tour of fascinating historical site
Review Text: We pre-booked a tour of this fascinating old gin producing mill. Our guide Eleanor gave us an historical background of the area around the Mill and then took us inside. It's in a state of partial restoration, the aim to get the Mill working again. It is reputed to be the largest Mill of its kind in the world. We wound our way through nooks and crannies, seeing the process of producing gin, if the Mill was working. Much of the original interior remains. An interesting, quirky venue for weddings and other events, already hosting musical events and craft fairs. We had quality sandwich lunch with good variety,at very reasonable prices, freshly made whilst we toured the Mill. Staff are volunteers thus all proceeds go directly to the restoration fund. Limited opening hours, check website, also don't confuse with another of similar name. Good walking along the canal path so we walked to Stratford Westfield.

Per un appassionato come me d'archeologia industriale non poteva che risultare interessante la visita a questo sito, l'isola dei tre mulini (anche se i mulini rimasti sono solo due). Probabilmente House Mill, costruito nel 1776, è il più grande mulino a marea rimasto al mondo, ha smesso di funzionare all'inizio della seconda guerra mondiale. Il Clock Mill, risalente invece ai primi anni dell'ottocento, ha smesso di funzionare negli anni cinquanta del novecento e oggi fa parte dei più grandi studi cinematografici londinesi. Si visitano solo di domenica, dalle 13 alle 16 da maggio ad ottobre (a quest'ultimo risale la mia escursione).
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Title: Joined up walking in East London - Queen Elizabeth Park to Three Mills is a delight in autumn
Review Text: The really nice activity at the moment is to walk along the Greenway now it has opened a direct link into the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park again. If you are going south on the Greenway just after the High Street crossing, look out for the  "Greek Orthodox  Pumping Station on the right and slip down a small path off the Greenway on the right, just keep going along the canal/river side then cross a little park and head for the Mill House building.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text:
The website for Three Mills Island says that there are lots of interesting things to see and do. The reality is that few oif the attractions were open when we visited on a weekend, and although the area is interesting to walk round, we were generally disappointed with the number of the attractions which were open to the public.

We wanted to visit the Abbey Mills Pumping Station - it was closed to the public. We wanted to visit the Farady Lighthouse - it was closed to the public. With one exception, the various historic buildings were closed to the public.

A disappointment!
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: Very interesting visit with a helpfulful guide around the House Mill. Interesting walks in the surrounding area
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Title: Three mills Studios - Al Murray Eventbrite Waste of Time
Review Text: Got guaranteed entry tickets for me and my disabled husband. After discovering there were no disabled services or parking we had to wait over half an hour before being searched for ‘sweets’ we were herded round to the studio. Another 10 minute wait while discussions took place only to be herded back to the entrance and told “sorry there are no more seats?” Then sent home. A free beer promised on arrival was not there, tickets said ‘only bottled water allowed in the studio’ but this was taken off us, searched for and sweets removed, unfriendly outside NON disabled toilets was a portacabin in the car park. I suggest staying well away from Eventbrite bookings as truth is completely missing from their promises and ‘guaranteed ticketed seating’ is just a con to get you there. Absolute waste of time, all future Eventbrite bookings now cancelled and will never use them again. Do not trust this organiser as you will most likely have wasted travel time. Btw my husband needed water to take medication but who cares? Not Eventbrite...
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text:
Went here for a recording of a new series called The Al Murray Great British Pub Quiz. No one looked at our tickets(!) and security were removing food and drink (including bottled water) from people. When asked if we would get those back, the guy said they would be on a table ready when you leave. I said what about if you want a drink whilst the show was recording and was told we would get bottled water in the studio... yeah work that one out? It was a lie as there was no bottled water available in Stage 6, so clearly lied too. 

The only toilets available were portacabin ones. Facilities here are dire. I've been to many recordings, Television Centre, The London Studios (now closed) and Elstree, never have we had food and water removed and all have provided inside toilets. 

I don't think I will be returning here again. If you are going, make sure that you consume any food before entering the complex and drink any water... oh and nip to the Tesco nearby if you want a pee in the warm with hot and cold running water.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text:
Brought one of our dogs out to the park and it was cold and windy. Great place for a picnic. 

Walk along the river and enjoy the view. Good exercise too.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: Great day out for family's who find it hard together out to a beach - the beach has been brought to the park complete with a couple of large play pools for young children and then castle building on the sand. Great idea £2 each to get in but that includes the fun fair which is expensive. Two good bars by the beach for adults. Parking at Westfield is also expensive £6.50 for over 2hours. The park could do with much more signs and direction boards but on whole a good day out.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: what a fabulous day l had with kids...great view at the top...l would say better than shard n with just a fraction of the price n best thing is...it,s valid for a whole year...thoroughly enjoyed our day
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Title: Excellent tour of House Mill, an atmospheric and historical industrial building with great views.
Review Text: We were given an excellent and fact-filled tour of House Mill (on Three Mills Island) by Geraldine – this historic industrial building is the last remaining tidal mill in London and although it is a bit dilapidated in places, it is grand and atmospheric and has great views over the canal which looks more like Bruges than London in places. There is a pleasant reception with a small shop, cafe and outside space by the canal.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: great views and reasonable price go up in the lift and come down the stairs and in the heart of the park its a must see for great views and look over the Olympic park
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: Проезжали на велосипеде. Отличное место для велопрогулок - пространство и виды. На три мельницы не заходили, но проехаться рядом стоит - вид  очень красивый, плюс осознание того, что это все ж таки киностудия )
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Title: Dejligt familievenligt område med minder fra OL 2012
Review Text: Det var dejligt at se, hvordan man kan bruge OL til at forskønne en bydel. Og hvordan genbrug og bæredygtighed kan forenes med så stor en begivenhed. Der er efterladt en dejlig park med gode aktiviteter til lokale beboere - og hele London. Der var en fin udstilling af dekorerede dobbeltdækkerbusser i miniformat da vi var der. Jeg var så heldig at være tilskuer ved OL i 2012, og det var dejligt at lukke øjnene, og genkalde nogle store moments fra OL. Bl.a. Jamiacas 4x100 m verdensrekord i finalen, som jeg fulgte på nærmeste hold.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: So I was wondering what we in Stratford were left after the Olympics had gone,Apart from the standing structures in the park there did not appear to be much,a park is a park is a park, a fun thing for the children was the lively dancing fountains in which they could splash, a not so fun thing was the solitary coffee stall which(in my opinion) served coffee not to a standard one would expect from a prestigious place.On the  whole I was not impressed but as works are still being carried out that impression may change in time.For a leisurely stroll however this is a good place to go if you like open spaces.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: What a great job they have done to regenerate this part of East London. Lovely open spaces walking and cycle paths. Play areas for children.  The sun was shining when we went on Easter Saturday although it was a little too cold for a picnic but I shall certainly be back in the summer to spend the day exploring the footpaths and waterways. Great way to get the kids away from the computer games and into the fresh air.
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Title: So lucky to have this on my doorstep..
Review Text:
Ok the sun was shining, but what a fab place to spend time. The kids did an hour and a half at the pool in the Aquasplash. 
Then a wander round the park, stopping at the climbing wall, play area and walks along the canal. There's so much we didn't see or missed - the water fountains, the velodrome, all the walks and more. So many families and a really great atmosphere. As we only live 10 mins away I think we will be back

If you take your kids shopping then they should drag you around here or just come here and do your shopping on the internet.....
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: What a transformation from ten years ago when this was an industrial wasteland. Congratulations to those involved in the transformation. A wide space for families to explore, water fountains and play areas for the children. Art works through out the huge expanse of the park. Lovely gardens and pathways to explore. The river path opened up. Grab a picnic from nearby Westfield and have a lovely day. (Still not convinced by that red helter skelter metal object, although we have not ventured up it for the views yet,)  The food kiosks in the park are not overpriced either. £2.30 bought an enormous 99 ice cream cone. Plenty of seating, a very pleasant experience.Glad to live in Newham!
Location: Three Mills and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park

Review Text: Ecological park makes it sound like there will be some wildlife there. It had some trees, bushes and overgrown reeds in the water, but no wildlife at all. Not worth a visit at all

Badly maintained park just like all other parks in the area. The park location has great potential as its a peninsula. Seems like the council isn't interested in improving the area at all. There isn't much to do here except for looking at wild growth and bushes. My suggestion, don't waste your time.

We found the site online and were intrigued but disappointed.  Perhaps we were expecting more bird and other animals.  The park is essentially a linear walk surrounded with trees and bushes. We saw no birds except a few gulls.  The peninsula is surrounded by water so would be pleasant relief on a hot day, but would not visit for potential bird watching.

If you look on the map on Trip Advisor this park is listed in East London. It's not. It's in South London, Croydon specifically.

Fortunately I used google to locate the park which is on the track bed of the former British Rail branch line from Elmers End to Addiscombe. Hence the name of the park. The route was converted to the Croydon Tramlink and the route diverted towards Croydon.

It's a nice, well maintained area and there is a small pond and flowerbed on parts of the park.

When I visited there were people using the park to enjoy the area including walking dogs and cycling.

The park closes at sunset so don't get locked in.

Addiscombe Railway Park - an update

I'm going to downgrade my previous review of the railway park to a single star. I stopped clearing rubbish from the railway park over winter 2021-22 but didn't restart when the weather got better in the spring because too many people obviously don't care about the environment and the litter problem has become so bad it's genuinely depressing. Part of the problem is that Croydon council didn't see the need to add more litter bins, but then they are financially restrained. The idea that care of Croydon's green spaces should be devolved to local groups isn't really an act of democracy but is rather another way to save money; a full partnership between the council and the local 'friends of' groups would be a better way of ensuring accountabilty, and may have prevented the parks being left unlocked at night. It's the night time when much of the littering - empty bottles and cans of alcohol - occurs, though drinking and casual recreational drug use is not uncommon during daylight hours. Dog faeces are another perennial problem, with no official patrols of the railway park to record breaches of the law or issue fines.
What was something of a haven during lockdown has become a nightmare, despite the best efforts of the volunteers, and until the government understands mental health issues and the relationship between declining mental wellbeing and the cost of living crisis, including providing much more money to local councils for upkeep of green spaces along with funds to ensure the provision of good local services, it's not going to improve any time soon.

This hidden park runs the old route of the railway line,  On my visit some parts were closed for refurbishment,  I found this by accident and so did not visit as an attraction but rather as a quiet place to walk in a busy city

Review Title: A valuable retreat, tended for by locals
Review Text:
Addiscombe Railway Park is a 1.3 hectare linear park between Blackhorse Lane tramstop and East India Way, laid along the footprint of the line between Woodside Junction and Addiscombe station.
The Addiscombe railway branch line was opened in 1864 following the acquisition of the Mid Kent Railway by South Eastern. It was closed in May 1997 to allow construction of Croydon Tramlink which uses part of the former route of the Woodside & South Croydon line, itself closed down in May 1983.
The station, demolished before full planning permission was granted, was turned into a housing development and the park site given over to Croydon Council by Bellway Homes in 2003. 
Addiscombe Railway Park was opened to the public on 26 May 2007 but suffered from flooding after heavy rain - the pathway crosses Norbury Brook somewhere around Dalmally Passage and the subsoil is impervious London Clay - since partially remedied by asphalting the surface to provide a cycle and footpath along much of its length.
Indigenous vegetation has been allowed to regenerate and over 1500 shrubs and young trees have been planted by the British Trust for Nature Conservation, creating a natural habitat for birds, wildlife and plants in the area. 
The industrial history of the site is commemorated with railway artefacts and signage made from old railway sleepers, and the entire park is tended by volunteers

This odd little device is supposed to show lunar phase, the lunar day and
cycles of the tide in graphical form on a dial at the top of the structure. To be honest, if a random person needs a PHD to work out what the dial is showing, then it needs a serious redesign.

Review Title: Interesting area that is better viewed on a sunny weekend
Review Text:
The area is interesting for it's history, the lighthouse, the 'container village' and the four ships. Sadly, on a cold Friday in late January the lighthouse and tge ships were closed off, so we will go back to see them on a sunny weekend day in the future.
One of the original buildings is re-purposed into an art gallery, which was the best part of our visit this time. The art that we saw was the finalists of John Ruskin Prize Exhibition, and the art was spectacular.
We had the chance to visit one of the in-house artists who was working in one of the container studios. He had time to show us his set-up and explained his art discipline. Around the container village are several art sculptures made by welding old bicycles, scrap copper cylinders etc. to create mobile sculptures. Sadly, none of them were moving and they didn't look as though they would move on a busy tourist day in the summer time either.
The Wharf has a lovely café called the Orchard Café. Great food, lovely views of the area through the large glass windows and fantastic staff.
We will go back and, on a sunny weekend, it may well get a 4 or 5 review.

But for ordinary, or perhaps extraordinary people, this temple to Victorian engineering would have been demolished .
Not only saved but loved back to much of it's caste iron magnificence.  And then these wonderful people turn out on a Sunday to guide and answer questions, nearly 50 of them.  This is where honours should be given not to the worthless politicians.

I visited here on the open house London in September 2015. After talking with my dad about it I had to visit and was lucky enough to see it. Was amazing and spurred me to then want to visit the Crossness steam day too. A must see if you get the chance.
Incredible architecture for its time and only constructed to promote the unseen work being undertaken beneath ground.

Review Title: I remember abbey mills when it was fully operational.
Review Text: My father was an electrician for Thames water in the 1970's,he was part of the team that kept the pumps pumping. In 1979 my father swapped Abbey mills for Broadholme treatment works in Rushden, Northamptonshire. Every now and then my old man would go back to London to see family and friends, on one of these trips he went back to Abbey mills to catch up with his old colleagues and I tagged along. I was five or six years old at the time and I can remember how fascinated and awestruck I was. One of my dad's old workmates had finished a maintenance job on one of the biggest pumps and I was given the privilege of starting it up. I can still remember being scared at the colossal noise that it made. My visit to Abbey mills is one of my fondest memories, they dont build em like they used to is a perfect description of this beautiful building. If ever you get the opportunity to take a tour of this amazing building you should grab it with both hands.
Book a visit when you can.  Its a working site - not a museum, and was done up (well) for the 2012 Olympics, because it was overlooked from the pathway which runs on top of the raised brick sewer.

I had no idea of the history of this place and thoroughly enjoyed the tour. The splendour of the refurbishment is incredible and the tour guides were knowledgeable and patient with questions. Definitively worth a visit but opportunities are few and far between.

Review Title: 😨 Sewer walk laid on by Thames Water ... brilliant👍
Review Text:
My second time visitng Abbey Mills Pumping Station.  It's a privilege to be able to see how everything works and it's hard to book a visit so look out for opportunities during Open Hoise weekend and apply early.  Restoration to the paintwork inside has continued apace and when finished it will be stunning.  

My visit this time included a sewer walk!  If you are in any doubt about doing it don't worry.  You get full protective clothing: disposable overalls, 2 layers of gloves, socks to put on over your own, thigh length wader boots, a hard hat and you are fully harnessed.  12 of us went down the sewer and 4 staff with bright torches so it wasn't scarily dark.  A man about 6' 2" stood up straight, there were only a couple of places where he needed to bend his head to go past.  It was one of my concerns that it would be a confined space which would trigger claustrophobia but truly, it's so big there's less space on a crowded rush hour underground train!  

Did it smell?  A bit, but it wasn't gag inducing, if you're worried put some Vicks or something like that under your nose.  Was it slippery?  Not really, the boots you have on have metal spikes in the soles and dig into anything soft so grip well.  Although it had rained a couple of hours before we went in the sewer there was only about 6" of water so nothing to worry about.  You get excellent briefing from the staff on what to expect.  You climb down a wall ladder and are fully harnessed and cannot fall, everyone managed it. You can take a camera but NOT a mobile phone to take pictures.  

We had an excellent talk about how the sewer system started and a talk and video about the new system being installed.  And to finish off we had the most wonderful lunch!  I highly recommend this experience.  Good luck with trying to book.  If you found this review helpful please tick the box.

Review Title: Viewed from the Greenway, a Victorian Gem
Review Text:
I read about Abbey Mills Pumping Station in Nairn's London.  He describes it as having elements of the Kremlin and Moorish architecture.  It is indeed a splendid pile to see. 

After visiting Three Mills nearby I mounted the Greenway via the Abbey Lane Open Space and wandered east along it several hundred metres until I came to a spot with a clear panorama of the buildings.  You can also take Abbey Road or West Ham DLR or the Jubilee / District / Hammersmith & City lines to West Ham.  

It would be an interesting place to tour; apparently, that opportunity is rare.  Take a walk along the Greenway to the QE Olympic Park and enjoy this as one of the sights along the way.  Also, check out Three Mills, which is a beautiful piece of architecture, too.

Review Title: Brilliant visit to Pumping Station and the Sewers
Review Text:
I was lucky enough - by the views of others - to get into an "open day" visit at the last minute. Thames Water did me proud!

I wasn't there for the buffet lunch, but it was excellent, but far too much for us to eat. My purpose was the lectures - absolutely excellent - about the history of sewage management and the develop of London sewers under the control of Bazalgette.  We then enjoyed an excellent, well-explained and very relaxed tour of the Pumping Station itself, followed by the primary purpose of my visit, the walk-through tour of the sewers. 

A short mini-bus hop to a nearby works site, then dressed up into our "sewer rat" uniform - socks, groin-high boots, two layers of gloves, a proper onesie, helmet, safety harness and box with gas mask!  Then we were clipped onto the safety system before descending the ladder into the huge sewer. Excellent commentary and explanations as we were guided through the c.1905 sewer up as far as a big junction and a view of the much older Bazalgette sewer - all of them so well built they never need rebuilding or - even - repointing!!  Back to base along the storm drain, adjacent to the sewer to cope with the - up to - 40 times increase in flow of a rainstorm. 

Thank you Thames Water ... and don't put fat down your sink, toilet or drain!!

Review Title: Rarely open to the public this working sewage pumping station is worth a visit
Review Text:
I entered a ballot for a place to go round Abbey Mills during Open House weekend.  It is a privilege to visit these buildings and although the tour was unstructured, the staff were very knowledgeable and happy to answer any questions.  The exhibition inside is very interesting but we didn't have enough time to look at it all properly and the map was so small and high up I couldn't really see it which was a shame.

I am pleased I went, however it is far less colourful inside than Crossness which is a true sight to behold.  There again Abbey Mills is still a working pumping station (fully automated) and Crossness has been lovingly restored by a dedicated team of volunteers.   It warrants a "Good" rating - so 3 1/2 stars really.

The outside of the building is worth a good look - take some binoculars if you want to see the higher up detail eg the Minton tiles and the weather vane which has a story all of its own. Get there by going to Abbey Road DLR, turn right, follow the road round and turn left into to Abbey Lane; Greenway was closed off for redevelopment when I went. 

Apparently there will be a tour of the pumping station in May 2016 which also takes in the sewers, you need to contact Thames Water to find out more.

Review Title: Rarely Open, But A Must See
Review Text:
You can walk past Abbey Mills pumping station by taking a DLR train to Abbey Road and then walking to the Greenway, which is the path on top of the Northern Outfall Sewer. 

The building is the northern twin to Crossness, but it doesn't have steam engines, although the building and engineering inside is impressive.

I got in once during one of Thames Water's Sewer Weeks, where I was also suited and booted and taken into the sewers under Hackney Wick. Who needs theme parks, when you can explore London's sewers?

For normal visits, it is often open during Open House weekends.

Crossness in South London and Abbey Mills, were London's two Victorian sewage pumping stations.

Abbey Mills is not generally open, although Thames Water does do occasional tours.

For those who like their engineering and architecture, as I do, it is a gem.

But if you walk past it on the Greenway, you can at least appreciate one of London's best pieces of Victorian architecture. Take the DLR to Abbey Road.
